The selective hydrogenation of gamma valerolactone (herein after GVL) into 2-methyl tetra hydrofuran (herein after MTHF) was studied over the different tungsten oxide-loaded Pt-doped H-Mordenite catalysts in a vapour phase continuous flow reactor. These catalysts were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, SEM, TEM, FT-IR, Raman, XPS, TPR, NH3-TPD and pyridine adsorbed FT-IR analysis. XRD analysis result suggests that the tungsten oxide was well dispersed at low tungsten oxide loadings and, the tungsten oxide crystallites were formed at higher tungsten oxide loadings and the crystalline structure related to H-mordenite was retained for all the synthesised samples. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis supported this result well. The TEM analysis confirms nano-sized platinum and tungsten oxide formation at 2Pt/10W-HM samples. The ammonia TPD analysis results suggested that all the samples possess weak and strong acidic sites and the amount and strength of acidic sites varies among the samples. The Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR results suggested that all the sample possesses mainly lewis acidic sites. These catalysts were evaluated for synthesising MTHF from GVL under different reaction conditions. Among the various synthesised catalysts studied, the 2 wt% Pt/10W-HM catalyst was identified as an effective catalyst with the 97 % conversion of GVL and the 98 % selectivity of MTHF. The higher catalytic performance depended on the distribution of surface tungsten oxide species along with the suitable acidic properties of the supported system. Introduction In the recent past, the world has faced some major problems, like the rapid depletion of non-renewable fossil fuel resources due to an increase in energy demand at the global level. Hence, finding alternative renewable resources to fossil fuel resources is important. Lignocellulosic biomass obtained from various resources, such as agricultural waste, etc., is a suitable alternative. It has many advantages: a more sustainable production process and a closed carbon cycle lead to reduced CO2 emission [1–3]. It is possible to derive many chemical compounds from lignocellulosic biomass using an aqueous phase process and the levulinic acid (LA) is one such important compound which has the potential to convert many other useful products such as gamma valerolactone (GVL), angelica lactone, 1,4 propane diol (1,4-PDO) etc. [4–6]. MTHF is used as a fuel additive to improve the octane number of the fuel and it is also found to be a promising solvent due to its peculiar physical and chemical properties in various chemical industries such as pharmaceutical etc. [7,8]. Since it is of great importance, it is necessary to have a sustainable process in synthesising MTHF. MTHF can be synthesised directly from levulinic acid. However, it yields a variety of products in the batch reactor, and harsh reaction conditions are also used [9,10]. This makes the process of direct MTHF synthesis not commercially viable. Moreover, it is possible to use GVL as the starting raw material for the production of MTHF since the synthesis of GVL from LA is a well-known process [11–13]. Hence, the selective synthesis of MTHF has been getting attention recently, especially in a continuous flow mode, to make the process economically viable in the industry. In literature, the conversion of GVL was studied over copper-based catalysts and the mixture of MTHF and 1,4-PDO was obtained with Cu/Al2O3 and selectively 1,4-PDO was obtained over Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalysts [14]. The Pt and Co catalyst was also used for the selective conversion of [15] GVL at the reaction temperature of 250 °C and pressure of 30 bar. However, this selective formation proceeds by hydrogenation to 1,4-propane diol as an intermediate, followed by subsequent dehydration, which leads to MTHF [16]. Hence, it is concluded that a suitable bi-functional catalyst i.e. redox and acidic properties, is required to obtain the selective conversion of MTHF from GVL. However, it is highly challenging to obtain MTHF selectively due to the complex and multiple reaction steps such as ring-opening, hydrogenation, dehydration, and cyclisation. Various [17] supported Pt-W catalytic systems are well known for glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction due to their bifunctional nature, i.e., composed of a transition metal (for hydrogenation) and an acidic promoter/or support [18,19]. Hence, our interest lies in this catalytic system, which could be a good choice for the conversion of GVL into MTHF. Zeolites are crystalline aluminosilicates and are found to have interesting properties and many advantages, such as well-organised porous structure, high surface area, and acid-base properties, which make an interesting support for many reactions [20,21]. Among them, Mordenite is a known large pore zeolite having 12 membered rings having properties like Lewis and Bronsted acidic properties, etc., and used as a solid acid catalyst in many industrial processes such as hydro-isomerisation, trans-alkylation reactions etc. [22–24]. Hence, due to these superior characteristic properties of the mordenite zeolite, it can be used as a solid acid support material for metal catalysts. Interestingly, these acidic sites of the zeolite can be further modified by the tungsten oxide species. In this study, we have synthesised different tungsten oxides loaded on Pt-doped H-Mordenite catalysts and studied the synthesis of MTHF from GVL. These catalysts were characterised with techniques such as XRD, Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis, FT-IR, SEM, TEM, Raman analysis, XPS, TPR, Ammonia TPD and pyridine adsorbed FT-IR analysis. The correlation between the catalyst properties and the catalytic activities during the GVL hydrogenation and the selective formation of MTHF were also studied. Experimental Catalyst preparation Synthesis of pt-wo3/h-mordenite catalyst The Tungsten and Platinum Precursors of the catalysts have been the ammonium meta tungstate hydride ((NH4)6(H2W12O40)H2O) and chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O) (analytical grade, produced by using Sigma Aldrich Co., Ltd), respectively. The catalyst was prepared using the sequential impregnation method at the H-Mordenite. The protonated form of the Mordenite zeolite (hereafter designated as HM) with a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 20 was obtained from Conteka, the Netherlands. Initially, a series of WOx/H-Mordenite catalysts with WOx loadings ranging from 5 to 20 wt% supported on H-Mordenite were prepared by impregnation method by adding an aqueous solution of ammonium meta tungstate to the calcined H-Mordenite support. After impregnation, the impregnated solid was dried at 110 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in air. The calcined tungsten oxide impregnated HM was further impregnated with a platinum precursor solution. The loading amount of Pt was set at 2.0 wt% for all the catalysts. The impregnated solid was dried at 110 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in air. These catalysts were named 2Pt/ xW-HM, where x-amount of WO3 was added. Similarly, yPt/10W-HM where y-amount of Pt added was prepared with the above-mentioned procedure. Catalyst characterisation The calcined forms of catalysts were characterised by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using a Rigaku miniflex X-ray diffractometer using Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15406 nm) from 2θ = 2 to 70° at a scan rate of 2° min−1 with the beam voltage and a beam current of 30 kV and 15 mA respectively. The IR spectra were recorded using IR (model: GC-FT-IR Nicolet 670) spectrometer by KBr disc method. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a Philips Fei Quanta 200F instrument operated at 20 kV. The sample was placed on a conductive carbon tape adhered to an aluminium sample holder and coated with Au. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were taken on a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 Spirit microscope (300 kV). The surface area and pore size distribution studies of the calcined catalysts were analysed using N2 adsorption at −196 °C by the multipoint BET method, taking 0.0162 nm2 as its cross-sectional area using Autosorb 1 (Quantachrome instruments). A Renishaw InVia Raman microscope with an excitation wavelength of 514.5 nm was used to get Raman spectra of the materials. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was measured with a Thermofisher spectrometer using monochromated Al Kα X-ray radiation. TPD experiments were also conducted on AutoChem 2910 (Micromeritics, USA) instrument. In a typical experiment, 0.1 g of oven-dried sample was pretreated by the passage of high purity (99.995 %) helium (50 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h. After pretreatment, the sample was saturated with highly pure anhydrous ammonia (50 mL min−1) with a mixture of 10 % NH3–He at 80 °C for 1 h and subsequently flushed with He flow (50 mL min−1) at 80 °C for 30 min to remove physisorbed ammonia. TPD analysis was conducted from an ambient temperature of 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The amount of NH3 desorbed was calculated using GRAMS/32 software. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) studies were conducted on an AutoChem 2920 (Micromeritics) instrument. For TPR experiments, about 0.05 g of the sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz sample tube. The catalyst was mounted on a quartz wool plug. Prior to the TPR studies, the catalyst sample was pretreated by passing a 30 mL min−1 N2 gas flow over it at 200 °C for 1 h. After pretreatment, the sample was cooled to ambient temperature and the TPR analysis was carried out in a 5 % H2-Ar flow (50 mL min−1) while heating from ambient temperature to 500 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. Py-FTIR experiments were performed on a Bruker FTIR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector in a range of 1000–2000 cm−1 with 32 scans. Catalyst testing The vapour phase hydrogenation of GVL was conducted in a vertical fixed bed quartz reactor (i.d.9 mm, 40 cm length) under atmospheric pressure. The catalyst bed is prepared by charging the catalyst in the constant temperature zone of the reactor, and a thermocouple is employed to control the temperature. Prior to the reaction, the catalysts were pretreated at 350 °C for 2 h in flowing H2 (60 mL min−1). After reduction, the reactor was cooled down to the suitable reaction temperature (160 °C – 220 °C) and fed with a GVL (flow rate: 0.5 ml/h) at WHSV 1.05 h − 1. Finally, the reaction products were condensed in an ice–water trap and collected for analysis every hour on a GC(Shimadzu) equipped with a DB-wax 123–7033 (Agilent) capillary column (0.32 mm i.d., 30 m long) and an FID detector. The conversion of GVL and product selectivity was quantified according to the following equations: Conversion ( % ) = moles of GVL ( in ) − moles of GVL ( out ) moles of GVL ( in ) × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = moles of specific product moles of all products × 100 Rate of the reaction was calculated using the following equation, Rate of reaction = Feed flow rate × Fractional conversion Weight of the catalyst Results and discussion Characterisation techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis X-ray diffraction patterns of various tungsten oxide loadings on platinum-doped H-mordenite samples are presented in Fig. 1 . From the literature it is known that the X-ray diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 9.77°, 13.45°, 19.61°, 22.20°, 23.16°, 25.63°, 26.25°, 27.67°, 27.87°, 30.89° and 35.61° are due to the pure H-Mordenite zeolite samples [JCPDS no 29–1257] [25,26]. The tungsten oxide sample will give X-ray diffraction peaks in the range of two theta of 23–25° The evident diffractive peaks with 2θ at 23.11°, 23.71°, 24.21°, 33.02°, 33.9° related to the (002), (020), (200), (202) and (220) crystal planes of a monoclinic phase of WO3 (JCPDS no. 43–1035), respectively [27]. The 2Pt/5W-HM sample has exhibited the XRD reflection peaks related to H-mordenite samples only. The absence of x-ray reflection peaks related to tungsten oxide and platinum indicates the existence of these metals in highly dispersed form over the support. While increasing the tungsten oxide loadings to 10 wt%, the extra peaks appeared in the two-theta region of 23.2°, 24.2°, 33.02°, and 33.9° These additional peaks are due to the crystalline WO3 peaks. Further increase of tungsten oxide loading to higher wt% (15 and 20 wt%), the intensity of the XRD peaks in these regions increased due to the formation of crystallite tungsten oxide species. However, a significant increase in the intensity was observed for the 20 wt% sample. The XRD analysis results (shown in Fig. 1) also suggested that the crystalline structure related to H-mordenite was retained for all the synthesised samples i.e. even after impregnation of both tungsten oxide and platinum. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis The surface area of the pure H-Mordenite zeolite sample was around 411 m2/g with a pore volume of 0.412 cc/g (Table 1 ). As the introduction of platinum (2wt%) and tungsten oxide (5wt%) into the H-Mordenite zeolite, the surface area of the sample decreases to 329 m2/g with the decrease of total pore volume into 0.271 cc/g. This result suggested the added platinum and tungsten oxide occupy the pores or pore mouth of the H-Mordenite zeolite, and as a result, the pore volume and surface area of the sample decrease significantly. However, a similar trend continues even with the increase of the tungsten oxide loading from 5 wt% to 20 wt% samples. Interestingly, all the sample exhibits better or higher surface area (279 – 379 m2/g), confirming that the porous nature of the H-Mordenite sample has not collapsed even after impregnation of the platinum and tungsten oxide compound and it can be evidenced from the XRD analysis also. SEM analysis SEM analysis results of various tungsten oxide loaded 2 wt% platinum doped H-Mordenite catalysts are shown in Fig. S1. The SEM images of 5 wt% tungsten oxide loaded samples exhibited the different sized plate-like particles in non-uniform shape. The SEM images of 10 wt% tungsten oxide loaded samples also demonstrated a similar morphology with almost no distinction. However, the SEM images of 15 and 20 wt% tungsten oxide loaded samples exhibited the crystallite particles in the SEM images (shown in Fig. S1c and d), which might be the existence of tungsten oxide crystalline particles. This result confirms the formation of well-dispersed tungsten oxide particles at low tungsten oxide loaded samples. In contrast, aggregated tungsten oxide particles are formed over the mordenite zeolite crystals at higher tungsten oxide loaded samples. The SEM-EDX mapping analysis of 2Pt/10W-HM sample confirmed the uniform distribution of platinum and tungsten oxide over the H-Mordenite zeolite samples (Fig.2 ). HR-TEM analysis The TEM analysis result of synthesised 2Pt/10W-HM catalyst is shown in Fig. 3 . The TEM images (shown in Fig. 3) clearly show the existence of the Pt particles. It is distributed randomly over the H-Mordenite zeolite (shown in Fig. 3b). The average size of the Pt was calculated. Interestingly, it exists in the nano-sized range around 2.6 nm for the synthesised 2Pt/10W-HM catalysts (shown in Fig. 3c). This result suggests that the Pt nanoparticle is well dispersed over the Mordenite zeolite support. Hence, this result proved the absence of X-ray diffraction peak of platinum in XRD analysis. Fig. 3a shows that the WO3 is present in a crystalline form, with an average size of around 15.7 nm, as determined from several pictures. FT-IR analysis FT-IR spectra of 2Pt/xW-HM catalyst with various WO3 loadings are presented in Fig. 4 . The existence of IR band in all the samples centred at 3400 cm−1 and 1620 cm−1 are due to the surface OH groups and bending mode of water molecule respectively. The IR band centered at 1064 cm−1 is attributed to the strong zeolite lattice band i.e. stretching vibrations of Si-O and Al-O band. With the increase of the tungsten oxide loadings over Pt-modified HM zeolite, there is an extra peak at around 802 cm−1 due to the W-O stretching vibrations in tungsten oxide and the peak intensity gradually increases with the increase of tungsten oxide content over the support. Laser raman analysis Fig. 5 illustrates the laser Raman spectra of various tungsten oxide-loaded Pt on H-mordenite catalysts. Laser Raman spectra of 2Pt/20W-HM catalyst exhibited the sharp, intense Raman bands at 260 cm−1, 700 cm−1 and 800 cm−1, indicating that the deformation, stretching and bending mode of the W-O-W bond of WO3 octahedral species respectively [28]. The less intense Raman band at 325 cm−1 is due to the tetrahedral tungstate species. This result indicates that the high tungsten oxide loaded sample (2Pt/20W-HM) possesses the tungsten oxide species in the crystalline species. Interestingly, in the lower loadings, the catalyst (2Pt-10&15 W/HM) exhibits a lower intensity of the bands, indicating less-sized crystalline WO3 particles over the support. This is due to the better dispersion of tungsten oxide species over the support at lower loadings. The 2Pt/5W-HM catalyst does not show any peak in the Raman analysis, indicating well-dispersed tungsten oxide species, which agrees with the XRD analysis results. NH3-TPD analysis The ammonia TPD profiles of 2Pt/xW-HM samples with various amounts of tungsten oxide are shown in Fig. 6 , and the total number of acidic sites of these samples is reported in Table 2 . The ammonia TPD profiles of 5 wt% tungsten oxide loaded sample showed a sharp peak at weak acidic regions and a broad peak at medium and strong acidic sites. With the increase of tungsten oxide loaded samples, these peak intensities do not change much. However, the position of the broad peak related to the medium and strong acidic sites shifted towards the low-temperature region, indicating the change in the strong acidic sites into moderate acidic sites in the samples. This effect might be due to the blockage of Bronsted acidic sites of the H-Mordinte zeolite by tungsten oxide species or due to the interaction of the tungsten oxide species with crystalline H-Mordenite zeolite. The total amount of acidic sites, which was reported in Table 2 shows that the number of acidic sites was higher for the 10 wt% tungsten oxide loaded sample and it decreases with further increase of the tungsten oxide loadings. This might be due to the formation of well-dispersed and small crystalline tungsten oxide species formation over the H-Mordenite zeolite for the 10 wt% tungsten oxide loaded sample, which was confirmed from XRD and TEM analysis, while the formation of bulk or bigger crystallites at higher tungsten oxide loaded samples (15wt% and 20 wt%). TPR analysis The TPR profiles of all the synthesised catalysts ranging from 5 wt% to 20 wt% tungsten oxide loaded 2 wt% platinum doped H-Mordenite catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . For better comparison, the pure mordenite zeolite samples are also shown in Fig. 7. The reduction peaks of tungsten oxide species from W6+ into W4+ generally appeared at higher temperature in the range of 650 – 700 °C [29,30]. The 2Pt/5W-HM catalyst exhibited only one reduction peak at 340 °C. The TPR profiles of 2Pt/10W-HM catalyst indicated a reduction peak at 340 °C and another broad reduction at high temperatures at 700 °C - 800 °C. The reduction peak, which appeared at low temperatures, i.e. below 500 °C in the TPR profiles, is due to the formation of surface tungsten oxide species by the hydrogen spillover process activated by platinum metal [25]. The reduction peak at higher temperatures is due to the reduction of bulk or bigger crystallites of tungsten oxide species over the mordenite zeolite. It is interesting to notice that the intensity of the reduction peak related to surface tungsten oxide species decreases, and the intensity of the reduction peak related to bulk or bigger crystallite tungsten oxide species increases with the increase of the tungsten oxide loadings. The 2wt%Pt-20wt% W/HM catalyst exhibited the high-temperature reduction peaks only in the TPR profile, confirming the formation of aggregated tungsten oxide particles at highly loaded samples. XPS analysis The XPS spectra of 2Pt/10W-HM catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . The W 4f XPS spectrum of Pt-W/HM catalysts is shown in Fig. 8f. The tungsten exhibited the XPS peaks of W 4f7/2 in Fig. 8f at the binding energy of 36.4 eV, indicating that the tungsten is in the higher oxidation state (W6+ ions). In general, the binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 peaks for metallic Pt, Pt2+, and Pt4+ ions exhibited the peaks at the binding energy of 71.5, 72.4, and 74.5 eV respectively. The Pt 4f XPS spectrum of 2Pt/10W-HM catalysts are shown in Fig. 8c. The Pt 4f XPS peaks at 72.0 and 74.6 eV in Fig. 8c confirms that the platinum (Pt), which is present in the 2Pt/10W-HM catalyst in the form of Pt2+ (PtO), and Pt4+ (PtO2) ions respectively. The XPS peaks at lower binding energy in Fig. 8c might be due to the Al 2p peaks since the Pt4f and Al2p both appear in the same region and might overlap. The O 1 s XPS peak that appeared at 531 eV might be due to the lattice oxygen of the mordenite support [31,2]. Pyridine adsorbed ft-ir spectroscopy Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra of various tungsten oxide loaded platinum doped H-mordenite catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . The intense Infrared band at 1446 cm−1 and Broad Infrared band at 1540 cm−1 which appeared in Fig. 9 are characteristic bands of Lewis (L) and Brønsted (B) acidic sites respectively. The infrared band appeared at 1490 cm−1 is the total acidic sites i.e. combination of both Lewis and Brønsted (L + B) acid sites. It is interesting to note that the intensity of the total acidic sites of the catalysts is proportional to the concentration of the acidic sites and it depends on the tungsten oxide loadings. The concentration of the acidic sites increases with increase of the tungsten oxide loadings upto 10 wt% and it decreases thereafter. This result is consistent with ammonia TPD results. Interestingly, the Bronsted acidic sites of the catalyst does not change much with change in the tungsten oxide loading henceforth, the Lewis acidic sites soley contribute to the total acidic sites as shown in Fig. 9. Catalytic activity Effect of pt loading The catalytic activity studies of hydrogenation of GVL over the synthesised catalysts with varying platinum content ranging from 0.5 wt% to 3 wt% were studied in the continuous vapor phase setup and the obtained results are presented in Table 3 . Confirming the impact of platinum and tungsten oxide, we conducted the GVL hydrogenation over H-mordenite support under standard reaction conditions. The results showed less than 2 % GVL conversion, with traces of 1,4 PDO, LA and MTHF obtained. For all the reactions over Pt loaded samples, the major products obtained are 2-MTHF, 1,4 PDO and valeric acid. In the case of 0.5 wt% Pt/10W-HM catalyst, it gave the GVL conversion of 67 % with MTHF selectivity of 68 %. The other products formed are 1,4 PDO and valeric acid, with a selectivity of 10 % and 7 %, respectively. This sample also yields the un-identified products with a selectivity of 15 %. The increase of the platinum content into 1 wt% over the 10wt% W-HM sample increases the conversion of GVL into 85 % and also the selectivity of MTHF into 78 %. As a result, the selectivity of other side products, such as 1,4 PDO and valeric acid, decreases to 8 and 7 %, respectively. A further increase of platinum content to 2 wt% over 10wt% W-HM sample increases the GVL conversion further into a maximum of 97 % with the 98 % selectivity of MTHF. Interestingly, valeric acid is the only side product with selectivity of 2 %. In order to improve our results further, the higher metal content of 3 wt% platinum over 10 W-HM sample was studied under similar reaction conditions and it was noticed that the conversion of GVL decreased slightly to 96 % with the selectivity of MTHF to 97 %. Hence, the maximum yield of MTHF was obtained over the 2 wt% platinum content over the 10 W/H-mordenite sample. This result shows that the high metallic content or hydrogenation activity is necessary for obtaining the maximum yield of MTHF. This result is well supported by gyula novadarszki et al., where the metallic content was necessary to acquire the high yield of MTHF [13]. Effect of WO3 loading In order to optimise the tungsten content, the conversion of GVL into MTHF was studied with different tungsten content ranging from 5 wt% to 20 wt% with optimum platinum content of 2wt% and the results are presented in Table 4 . The 5wt% tungsten oxide loaded sample showed the conversion of GVL of 75 % with 78 % selectivity of MTHF. With an increase of tungsten oxide content to 10wt%, the GVL conversion and the MTHF selectivity increase to 97 % and 98 %, respectively. As the rise in tungsten oxide content increases, the GVL conversion decreases with a decrease in the MTHF selectivity. Interestingly, the samples with higher loadings of tungsten oxide yield products like 1,4 propane diol, valeric acid, and other unidentified products with considerable yields. From Table 4, the maximum yield of MTHF was achieved over 10 wt% tungsten oxide samples. Hence, the optimum tungsten oxide loading was fixed as 10 wt%. Gyula Novadarszki et al. studied the hydrogenation of GVL in a continuous flow reactor over Pt supported on MAG catalyst and obtained the valeric acid selectivity of 80 % with the GVL conversion of 90 % [16]. Qiang Liu et al. studied the transformation of GVL into 1,4-propane diol and MTHF over Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst and found that the high MTHF selectivity was observed over Cu/Al2O3 catalyst. When the introduction of zinc into the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst blocks the acidic sites; as a result, better 1,4-propane diol was observed [14]. Fig. 10 Domenico Licursi et al. studied the conversion of levulinic acid and found that Ru-Re/Carbon and NbOPO4 as co-catalyst increases the selectivity of MTHF due to the nature of having both Bronsted and Lewis acidic sites in NbOPO4 catalyst [32]. GyulaNovadarszki et al. observed that to get a high yield of MTHF, the maximum amount of metallic content is necessary for the catalysts [16]. Pravin P. Upare et al. studied the direct hydrocyclization of levulinic acid to MTHF over nanocomposite Cu/SiO2 catalysts in the vapor phase and obtained the maximum MTHF yield of 64 % over a high copper content catalyst at reaction temperature 265 ℃ and 25 bar H2 pressure. The authors showed that the selectivity to MTHF can be tuned by the metal loading while increasing the Cu loading increases the MTHF yield [33]. Du et al. exhibited the effect of calcination temperature of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst with yield of MTHF and 1,4 PDO. When the Cu/ZrO2 catalyst was calcined at 400 ℃ yielded 93 % selectivity of MTHF with 98 % GVL conversion. This study was conducted at an aqueous phase at 60 bar pressure and 240 ℃ reaction temperature [29]. From this, it can be observed that the optimised acidic sites, as well as metallic or redox sites, are required to obtain the maximum selectivity of MTHF. Hence, the correlation of the rate of methyl tetrahydrofuran formation with acidic sites and redox sites was carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 9. Among all the samples synthesised, the samples with 10 wt% WOx loaded sample, having the optimum yields of surface WOx species (from TPR analysis results) and the maximum number of acidic sites i.e. mainly lewis acidic sites leads to the formation of maximum amount of MTHF yield (shown in Fig 9). The samples with higher tungsten oxide content, i.e. 15 wt% and 20 wt% possess lower acidic sites and the lack of surface WOx species due to the agglomeration of tungsten oxide leads to lower yield of MTHF. Similarly, in the case of various amounts of Pt impregnated over 10WO3/HM samples, the low amount of Pt loaded samples (0.5wt%) exhibited low MTHF yield and with an increase of Pt amount, the yield of MTHF also increases. Hence, the 2Pt/10W-HM sample possesses suitable acidity and hydrogenation ability to obtain the maximum yield of MTHF (98 %). Table 5 Reaction pathway The exact mechanism for the conversion of GVL into MTHF has not been established yet. However, the reaction pathway for this conversion was proposed by many authors. According to the literature, in the first step of the hydrogenation of GVL, a 2‑hydroxy-5-methyltetrahydrofuran intermediate is formed. Further, the CO bond cleavage on the side of the methyl group and subsequent hydrogenation leads to valeric acid. In contrast, the CO bond cleavage on the side of the hydroxyl group leads to the formation of 1,4 pentane diol or 2,3 dihydro-2- methyl furan and subsequent dehydration and cyclisation leads to the formation of MTHF [13]. Hence, the catalyst with suitable acidic sites and redox sites yields MTHF, whereas the less acidic sites and high hydrogenation ability yield more of 1,4 propanediol and valeric acid. Effect of reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature on hydrogenation of GVL into MTHF was studied between the temperature range of 160 °C – 220 °C over 2Pt/10W-HM sample and the results are presented in Fig. 11 . The temperature has also played a major role in the MTHF yield. The GVL conversion increases with an increase in temperature from 160 °C – 220 °C. In the case of hydrogenation of GVL into MTHF, the 1,4-propane diol intermediate formation is considered as the rate-determining step [30]. This step involves the breaking of the C–O bond followed by the hydrogenation process, which requires a higher reaction temperature. It is interesting to note that the selectivity of MTHF was around 78 % when the reaction temperature was 160 °C, and it increases with the increase of reaction temperature until it is 200 °C. At lower reaction temperatures, the major side product is 1,4 propane diol. At lower temperatures, the dehydration property of the catalyst is very low; as a result, the maximum yield of 1,4 propane diol is observed. Further, an increase in reaction temperature to 200 °C enhances dehydration, increasing MTHF selectivity with the expense of 1,4-propane diol selectivity. Further increase of reaction temperature increases the valeric acid selectivity and other unidentified products, decreasing the selectivity of MTHF to 92%. From this, it is observed that the higher temperature favours the cleavage of CO bond on the methyl side, leading to valeric acid formation. Hence, the reaction temperature also plays an important role in obtaining the maximum yield of MTHF. Time on stream The time on stream studies (TOS) of hydrogenation of GVL into MTHF was carried out at the reaction condition of 200 °C over 2Pt/10W-HM for 24 h and the results are presented in Fig. 12 . The conversion of GVL was stable upto initial 12 h thereafter slight decrease in the conversion was noticed upto TOS of 24 h. Interestingly, the selectivity of the MTHF was stable even up to the TOS of 24 h. Hence, this catalyst is highly stable for obtaining the maximum yield of MTHF. To know the reason for the decrease in the catalytic activity after TOS of 12 h, the spent 2Pt/10W-HM, i.e. after TOS of 24 h, was characterised with various analyses. Spent catalyst characterization CHN and icp analysis The carbon-hydrogen analysis results of fresh 2Pt/10W-HM sample and spent 2Pt/10W-HM sample are shown in Table S1. Interestingly, the spent sample has more carbon (2.54 %) than fresh samples. Hence, the decrease in conversion of GVL after TOS of 12 h could be due to the formation of carbon over the samples. In addition, the fresh and spent catalysts were examined by ICP analysis to verify the content of platinum and tungsten and the results are summarized in Table S2. The Pt and W contents of the fresh and spent samples were determined to be 1.85 and 1.79 wt.%, and 7.41 and 7.26 wt.%, respectively. Based on the results, there is no significant leaching of platinum and tungsten observed. TEM analysis The TEM images of the spent catalyst revealed that the Pt particles become larger (average 5.7 nm) (shown in Fig. 13 ) during the time on stream. It might also be a cause for the deactivation of the catalyst. Fig. 14 Many reports were found on GVL to MTHF conversion in the fixed bed and batch reactors over various Nobel and non-Nobel catalysts at various operating conditions. In batch reactions, the Cu-Ni/Al-Zr bi functional catalyst achieved high efficiency, 99 % yielding MTHF from LA in the presence of 2-butanol at 220 °C and 3 MPa H2 pressure, the Al-Zr support acidity in promoting synergistic interactions between Cu and Ni species were responsible for higher activity [9]. In fixed-bed conditions, Ni -Cu/SiO2 catalyst showed an excellent yield of MTHF (89 %) at 265 °C and 2.5 MPa H2 pressure in a 1,4-dioxane solvent [33]. Overall, the reported catalysts achieved higher activity at high H2 pressure (1 to 10 MPa). This 2Pt/10W-HM catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity in terms of GVL conversion (97 %) and MTHF selectivity (98 %) at 200 °C and atmospheric H2 pressure owing to its high surface acidity and Pt dispersion. Conclusion In short, the different wt% of WOx loaded over 2Pt/HM catalysts were synthesised by sequential impregnation methods and tested for the hydrogenation of GVL into MTHF in the continuous mode vapour phase setup. Interestingly, all the synthesized catalysts were found to be active for hydrogenating GVL into MTHF. Considering attaining a maximum MTHF yield, this reaction has been optimised by investigating different amounts of platinum and tungsten oxide content and reaction temperatures. Among the tested reactions, the 2Pt/10W-HM sample exhibited the maximum GVL conversion of 97 % with MTHF selectivity of 98 % at the reaction temperature of 200 ℃ at WHSV-1.05 h − 1. However, this sample is highly stable for TOS of 24 h, with slight deactivation found after TOS of 12 h due to the formation of carbon over the active sites and increased Pt particle size. Various techniques and the results characterized this sample suggest the presence of well-dispersed and crystalline WOx species over the surface of mordenite zeolite. Therefore, it contains a maximum number of acidic sites and suitable redox sites, responsible for the maximum yield of MTHF from GVL. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of gamma valerolactone (herein after GVL) into 2-methyl tetra hydrofuran (herein after MTHF) was studied over the different tungsten oxide-loaded Pt-doped H-Mordenite catalysts in a vapour phase continuous flow reactor. These catalysts were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, SEM, TEM, FT-IR, Raman, XPS, TPR, NH3-TPD and pyridine adsorbed FT-IR analysis. XRD analysis result suggests that the tungsten oxide was well dispersed at low tungsten oxide loadings and, the tungsten oxide crystallites were formed at higher tungsten oxide loadings and the crystalline structure related to H-mordenite was retained for all the synthesised samples. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis supported this result well. The TEM analysis confirms nano-sized platinum and tungsten oxide formation at 2Pt/10W-HM samples. The ammonia TPD analysis results suggested that all the samples possess weak and strong acidic sites and the amount and strength of acidic sites varies among the samples. The Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR results suggested that all the sample possesses mainly lewis acidic sites. These catalysts were evaluated for synthesising MTHF from GVL under different reaction conditions. Among the various synthesised catalysts studied, the 2 wt% Pt/10W-HM catalyst was identified as an effective catalyst with the 97 % conversion of GVL and the 98 % selectivity of MTHF. The higher catalytic performance depended on the distribution of surface tungsten oxide species along with the suitable acidic properties of the supported system.
coredata.dc:title: Engineering acidic and Pt sites on WO3- doped H-mordenite supported Pt catalyst for hydrogenation of γ -valerolactone to methyl tetra hydrofuran
